job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Calgary, AB
pros: Zero run while you can.
cons: Your on here because you just got a job offer for 40-45K base with a 2% commission from cdi DONT do it. Let me tell you my story ever since I joined this college I’ve lost self confidence in myself, I used to get severe anxiety in the morning thinking who am I going to enroll today? Do I still have a job because I didn’t harass the crap out of a student to enroll? Are you familiar with nepotism? Well that’s what it’s like here. You will be compared with admission reps who’ve been here for years ( only because there losers and can’t find anything better and are milking the college for as long as they can). Do you enjoy working in the weekends ? Well your in for a treat as you will be expected to start “ building your business during the weekend”. Most of the students who entertain cdi are oppressed , single mums, or overall struggling in life. Yeah, those are the people YOU will need to sell $20,000+ course and tell them what they want to hear which is? “ you will get hired with a cdi diploma don’t worry” and you knowing well they will not find any employment as long as cdis names on it. Guys and gals please take my advice , I went through hell here and i will never ever tell anyone to join this college. They have a bad reputation and won’t be here for long.

job_title: Student Finance Planner in Scarborough, ON
pros: Nobody cares what you do, so if you are unethical you will have a good time.
cons:
Worst management ever - 22 year old highschool dropout is a manager who has zero idea on how to deal with people. She tells stories about how she passed out after drinking on the weekend. Total power crazed psychopath with narcissistic tendencies. She quotes blog.to instead of canada.ca to know which are federal holidays. Sent out an email with a holiday schedule, was a holiday on the HR page…but cancelled the day off 2 days before the day and when confronted, she just left the conversation hanging and literally left. Played politics with employees to get them fired and show her power.

NO JOB SECURITY - 3 weeks into the job half the staff was laid over because they did not have enough work (this was not covid related as the branch opened in 2021). The location now due to lack of work has been closed off. 

VERY UNETHICAL AND PROBABLY ILLEGAL - I left the company when I was told that I should help a 65 year old lady apply for student funding for a course of cyber security. She did not know what a mouse was when I called her to help. No one explained the course to her they just wanted the money. Multiple lawsuits going on. Can google it to find out its public info. Did not give me my break out of spite (another dirty power move) which I am legally entitles to. Did not eat lunch that day.

Have fun at CDI. I hope someone sues company to have then shut down. TOTAL SCAM!!! WONT EVEN ADD ON MY RESUME FOR NEXT JOB!! Will hurt me more than do any good

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Calgary, AB
pros: You might meet alot of new people
cons: This is by far the worst sales job ever. The management will use you to do alot of cold calling. The recruit in batches of 40 and have you fighting to get fresh leads. You eventually get the fresh leads and most of them turn out to be trash. There is alot of pressure to get at least 2students enrolled every week, even though you have crappy leads. When you do not, you will get fired. I had to quit this job for my mental health and sanity. The school itself does not offer accredited programs. You will end up getting students enrolled in programs that they cannot use the certificates, upon graduation. The job will definitely make you feel worthless. They even make you come in during weekends, and you do not get paid for it. You can also rest assured that you will never see a commission cheque in your life.

review_title: Terrible place to work! AVOID IT!!!
pros: -The people are nice to work with.
cons:
-The pay is absolute garbage for what they expect you to do.
-The managers don't know what they are doing, so they micromanage their staff.
-Everyone is depressed and hates their job. There was one employee who told me the only thing he liked about his job was his desk because it was beside a window.
-The benefits are a joke. You have to work there for 12 months to qualify for 4 paid sick days. You have to work for a year to qualify for 2 weeks of paid vacation.
-It is a toxic work environment where you don't feel valued or appreciated as an employee.
-You work 8.5 hours with 1/2 hour "paid" lunch break and two 15 minute coffee breaks that nobody has time to take.
-There is no lunch room in the office, which is cramped and full of tiny cubicles.

job_title: Student Financial Planner in Burnaby, BC
pros: The people you actually work with are cool folks.
cons: Management is very profit-driven to the detriment of the students. They refuse to receive any form of feedback and have a "do as we say" mentality, even if they promise you that they're listening. Toxicity is ignored if it's done by the sales team.

pros: Great staff, depending on which campus you work at
cons: Disorganized and poor management in some campuses.

pros: They let you do whatever you want and take whatever breaks you feel like.
cons:
Fired a whole floor once, including Student Financial Planners who were on the phones completing applications with students. They told them to hang up and gave them their resignation package.
Management does not care about people, only cares about money. Says they'll give referral bonuses for new hires then fires staff right before they can collect. 6 month wait before any commission, often fires staff before they can collect that and pockets all commissions for management.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Vancouver, BC
pros: Good experience, fancy title. Nice big office. Do not work here. It is not worth it.
cons: Extremely high pressure and stressful. You get WEEKLY sales targets. If you hand in 5 enrollments one week and then 1 the next, you will get angry calls. You will have your job threatened. Whether you meet, do not meet, or wildly exceed expectations they will threaten to fire you basically every week. The management structure is extremely toxic. No one lasts very long. The commission is A JOKE. They push you and push you and the commission is incredibly delayed and a joke. It is so much work that you should have two or three people doing the job, and your student services team is so underpaid and overworked it is insane. No opportunity for growth. Basically don't even look at the commission when you plan your expenses for the year as it is not much to speak of. Basically it is extremely stressful, you have enough work for two people, weekly sales targets, and if you mess up for one week you are super replaceable. They get pissed if you take your vacation days and expect you to work 70 hours a week all unpaid overtime. No joke. 70 hours a week. If you clock out at 6 you will get told you don't look like you value the company and have no work ethic. The management structure is so bad it is difficult to put into words. They follow all these metrics that encourage staff to make things up to meet their appointment set and referral quota. It is all money and unfortunately, if you are an integrity person it is not good. People basically work until they start getting angry calls, getting stressed and not feeling valued, and then they quit and are replaced in a week.

review_title: Whatever you do, don’t work here
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Surrey, BC
pros: The base pay is decent. Commissions available to be made, just make sure you’re keeping track of what you’re expected to earn as there will always be discrepancies not in your favour.
cons: The leads that are promised to you are mostly fake, and if they are at all promising they are given to the “favourites” in the office. You are expected to make 100 dials a day, and if haven’t been given any new leads you are stuck calling people who have already informed the school that they are no longer interested. If you do receive a new lead they expect you to call them 4 times minimum the first day, and then everyday after that until you make contact. If you do happen to enrol a student don’t expect them to receive a quality education, some “professors” actually inform their students that they don’t have enough time to grade their work, and that they will have to get their peers to grade their work for them. There is an extremely high turnover rate from both people being terminated, but also people quitting. The highest up manager is a bully and is known to yell and belittle employees when they are just trying to do their job. The management under the highest up isn’t much better with micromanaging and promoting a toxic work environment.

pros: It's like a family !!!
cons: It's a dysfunctional family though

pros: nothing really. you get to meet a couple great people for about 3 weeks before they leave
cons: everything. the most abusive and toxic place to work

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Calgary, AB
pros:
Commission system, paid training at central location.
Fancy title.
cons:
You have to get on board with telling white lies to get your sign ups and meet your quotas (eg. Spots are limited! For an online course? Really?) 
You have to somehow morally be ok with selling prospective students on this college and its sister colleges.
Just keep doing your own research, check out some more reviews on other sites too, and see for yourself how much of a scam this "college" is, along with Reeves and Vancouver Career College, two colleges under the same management which garner similar reviews.
I was only able to attend my first day because I then had a chronic pain flare-up, due to how incredibly stressed I felt about the idea of using sneaky sales tactics, to sell admissions to a school that isn't properly accredited, nor staffed by experienced teachers, just so that I could get a cut of their tuition. 
I've read that some employers actually blacklist CDI graduates, using applicant tracking systems to filter through resumés.
Fancy title is meaningless, there are at least two hundred ADOA's. It's just to make prospective students feel like they're getting special treatment from someone important.
High quotas, including 100 calls a day or like 6 interviews or a mix of the two, and if you can't meet all of the different quotas they've assigned to you by a certain point (3 months I think), you're fired.
I simply can't imagine why there's such a high turnover rate. I haven't even gotten into the tactics we were instructed to use - one of which is calling a cold lead pretending to be a different employee from a different department, in order to find out why they didn't sign up (and try to solve that problem), and hear what they truly thought of you. The MOST innocuous tactic involves buttering up your client and making them feel like they're a smart guy making a smart decision by "investing in their education". Eye roll emoji, air quotes.

review_title: The Most Disorganized Company I've Ever had the Displeasure of Working For
job_title: Student Financial Planner in Burnaby, BC
pros:
- I've heard the on-ground campuses are alright, but steer clear of the online division. 

The hiring requirements:
- You have a pulse
cons:
The Management:
- Some of the most insufferable and incapable upper management I have ever seen in all my working years
- Problems are addressed but never solved and are cyclical in nature.
- They don't understand your role at all and will request absurd things from you because of that. It's because everyone is hired from outside.
- They will request you to obtain something from a student that does not exist, due to the fact they actually have no idea of how anything in your position works. (because everyone in upper mgmt is an outside hire)
- They will pretend to resonate and hear your voice.
- All the problems I will be outlining stems from the incapabilities of upper management

How they treat their employees:
- They don't believe in giving employees a raise. Don't waste your time here. If you've been here for a year, you still won't get a raise.
- No paid sick days.
- Extremely high employee turnover rates across all departments. They have to keep hiring new people because the more experienced ones are leaving, leaving absolutely nobody capable to work.
- You quite literally have to learn everything on your own.

The operations:
- Extremely inefficient, as I will outline below
- They change the way they do things every month because nothing they suggest ever works. Seriously.
- The sales team management are ONLY concerned about getting their numbers, and are willing to jeopardize and disregard everything on the SFP's side just to achieve that , generating more work for us - only to follow it up with a simple, "Sorry, it won't happen again". Spoiler alert: it will happen again.

The Values:
- Their motto is, "We Change Lives Through Education". This is the funniest thing I have ever read. They certainly do, by pressuring their sales team to force the student to sign the papers to get them enrolled, disregarding the financial planner's advice on the student's financial assessments, ultimately leaving the student in crippling debt. They have certainly changed their lives through education.
- Forcing homeless students to take on $25,000 in loans.

The way they handle COVID-19:
- They don't enforce any employee health checks when entering the office during Covid-19, as dictated under section 42 of the Public Health Act. This is illegal, right?
- Building management sending out violation emails every other month
- Health Authorities keeps coming back to check on health violation reports every 4 months
- They put more effort into keeping employees from working from home than they do in fixing their actual problems

review_title: Don't work or study at CDI!!!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Calgary, AB
pros:
Impressive sounding but misleading job title. This is nothing more than redundant cold call telemarketing. The requirements to being an Assistant Director of Admissions at CDI College are:

- Having a pulse
- Having your resume available for public viewing on Indeed as they hire 12-30 people for this role every 2 weeks and are lucky to have 1 person out of each hiring group stay for longer than 3 months.
cons:
- Cramming over 100 people into an office during COVID. 

- They want you to make 100 calls a day but only give you 1-2 leads a day. People are encouraged to harass leads until they tell you to stop calling them. Mostly just beating a dead horse. Calling people that have already been harassed enough by CDI College. It is rare that a lead answers the phone. When people do answer most of them would ask me " what is CDI college?" - low quality leads.

- Pressured to work evenings and weekends for free.
 
- In my first 2 weeks there lots of people had feedback from leads saying that the number we were calling from shows up as spam. They changed the number and a week later that number was showing up as spam/possible fraud. They then started to encourage everyone to call leads from their own cell phone. They will not be paying your cell phone bill. 

- students complain about the quality of education, disorganization, and materials not being available. 

- Over priced courses. Don't pay thousands of dollars to learn how to use Outlook, Word and Powerpoint, just google it or search on youtube. 

- hypocritical messages from upper management

- micromanagement

- very very poor training

Would rate this 0 starts if Glassdoor would allow it.

review_title: Lack of competent corporate communication and leadership
pros:
Most of the the campus instructors take pride and effort to teach the students to the best of their ability.  They work well with the staff to create an integrated support environment for the students. 
Staff commitment to students are high, but are being challenged by poor support from management.
cons:
Poor recruitment filtering. Admissions is in a profit first mentality and some students who do not have the right language or skills prerequisites are enrolled, creating frustration among students and the instructors. 
Poor communication from corporate management.  Structural and employee changes can happen at a moment. Campus Directors typically do not last more than a year in this campus.
Poor employee support.  I never recieved any raises during my time there, eventhough I was promised some after my probationary period. There were no yearly employee reviews done either, and requests for them were delayed and brushed aside.

pros: The ability to teach/instruct students towards the completion of their educational goals.
cons: Where do I start? The corporate culture is non-existent. If you take your job seriously, the slacker staff get intimidated as it then highlights their own incompetence. Management is there for the paycheck. Students are not their #1 priority...nor is staff health. The company is run by greedy owners who ultimately just care about the bottom line. If you are seeking a job at CDI College anywhere in Canada, be prepared to work for peanuts and have to kiss a lot of butt cheeks. I worked at two locations and it is the same everywhere. The bottom line is that no one really cares about you. Good Luck.

pros:

I was working in a central downtown location
cons:
Very high turnover in the region 
Working conditions can become toxic, very quickly 
I had issues receiving bonuses and salary adjustments on time
Very shady overall feel

Reviews for most campuses are atrocious
I would recommend to do a Google search on Peter Chung and Eminata group
Corporation is downsizing. The company is not what it used to be in 2008-2012. No longer worth your time unless, you are desperate or know someone personally in head office

pros: Great students who are very motivated to learn.
cons: The online system for instructors & students is inconsistent between courses which creates lots of "surprises" for instructors. Most instructors are part-time and only paid for 4 hours per day of actual instruction time despite the necessity for daily prep every night  if you want to be a decent instructor. All statutory holidays and vacation pay are paid out of your hourly wage, so you aren't actually paid for the hourly wage in your contract ("exclusive of holiday and vacation pay"). Yes, folks, CDI is so cheap you pay for your own statutory and vacation pay.

review_title: things you should know before signing
pros: start any time and only 4 hours per day
cons:
projects and home work do not leave time for a job and the funding is sold far short of what you are entitled to
 
2019-20 Monthly Living Allowance:

 	Household Status	Monthly Total (CAD$)
No dependent children	Single, not paying rent	575
Single, paying rent or mortgage	1,199
Married/Common Law without children	2,313
With dependent children	Single parent with one child	2,118

review_title: Chaos, Drama, Not worthy of Professional Education
pros: Flexible, Activities, Fair Pay, Work-Life Balance.
cons: Privately run. Drama (mostly females) from colleagues. Students are drop-outs or with no hope. Here instructors must obey students not the opposite normal behavior, students can insult and threat instructors and its ok with management because they are paying $$$. Cash Cow institution not thriving on delivering true education unlike publicly-run counter-parts. Students can retake exam so many times to stay, and they can miss as many classes as they wish without repercussions. As an instructor you will quickly drain-out if you keep on comparing your university-time experience to the chaotic environment at CDI college!

review_title: Bad, and getting worse by the week. If it's CDI or starvation... starve!
pros: Most co-workers are very nice.
cons: Upper management doesn't even pretend to care about the students or staff. The only thing that matters is money. Poor quality education at a cost greater, per year, then attending the University of Alberta School of Law. Yes you read that right. 75% staff turn over/ year seems to be common, and not a concern. Expected to work 8-8 M-F plus Saturdays. No concern for burn out at all, you can be replaced, and you will hear that often.

pros: Quitting and leaving was my greatest accomplishment here
cons: Honestly everything about this place. They hire their own students so no real talent teaches the students that just dropped 12k on a diploma. Anyone they do hire with real education leaves because they see this garbage fire instituion and take off for the hills

pros: Some flexibility.
cons:
Most instructors are not experienced as instructors, nor do they have sufficient experience in the field. Its a plus, if you want to have this job and don't have the experience. 

Managers/Directors have no experience in education, never taught in a classroom, and also have no management experience. You get hired in those positions because of the connections that you have. Females have more chances of attaining that position. The plus side is that your ego in this position really grows because you are in position of authority and you can finally rule a campus with threats of firing the employees. 

Students are the lowest concern at the college. This is also a plus, because it means that you really don't have to do job while you are at your job. After all, the main goal of any organization should be to make money. Unless, the students have made a complaint to the ministry. Then the student becomes the most important person until the issue dies down. 

Employees are also the lowest concern at the college. If a student complains against the instructor, the best way to deal with the problem is to completely ignore what the instructors point of view on the matter is, in fact, don't even tell him that there is a complaint against him. 

Speaking of saving money; no ones job is safe ever, nor is your salary. If a director barely dislikes you, they can fire you, after telling you that your job is secure and you have nothing to fear. 

All the upper management is filled with ego. There is a lot of regional directors in absolutely useless places, who are completely out of tune of the needs of the campus and the students and the employees.

pros: Friendly people to work with.
cons: Not getting a raise in 3 years people have had to go and get second jobs just to make life easier. No cares that good instructors have left and moved on to better paying jobs, not that money is everything but when the cost of living has gone up so should pay. There is no appreciation for stuff at all anymore that was all taken away.

review_title: Selling Dreams, while their employees suffer
pros: Flexibility, if you needed a day for an appointment or family emergency it was given.
cons: There was zero to no training. Sister campus that are suppose to be there for support turn their nose at you like you are trying to undermined them. Each department has a VP, Director, Executive director which are either in a different region or have loyalty to their campus so support was not given. Campus directors are just puppets with ZERO control over their campus. Education management is all over the place with zero organization, student will ask administration where their classes are, where they can get their schedules student ID's. Instructors are very territorial, no team players to help students that are struggling.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Calgary, AB
pros: The "possible" commission you could make
cons:
Highly competitive
The expectations that you basically work 7 days a week
The fact that you're supposed to harass people to enroll in school
The overpriced tuition for programs
The over promise of 100 leads per month 
I could continue but save yourself the headache and don't do a sales job

pros: Great work colleagues and amazing environment. Students are very eager to learn. Simply love the whole vibe of this place.
cons: Most instructor positions are part time and that is the only con I can think of. I would love to work full time here.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Montreal, QC
pros: The Campus I worked at had great staff.
cons: Upper Management only cares about profit. Forcing programs on would be students to fill a quota. No real care for the employees and no forethought for the company. The training was abysmal ( 3 Days of Nothing ). They put no effort or money into the campus's. The Cheapest Company I have ever worked for.

pros: Amazing working with and seeing students academically grow.  Good for obtaining experience.
cons: Pay is not at all competitive, charge students a great deal of money yet they penny pinch when it comes to staff or providing resources.

pros: The staff bond well together and work closely with students to help them learn the material.
cons: At times, you can be frustrated with not being able to help a student due to rules and regulations. But this is rare and the staff and faculty do what they can to help.
